title: Mark Minkov
text:
Mark Anatolievich Minkov (; 25 November 1944 – 29 May 2012) was a Soviet / Russian music composer. His music is featured in a number of <a href="opera">opera</a>s, <a href="ballet">ballet</a>s, stage performances, and <a href="film">film</a>s.
He composed the scores for more than a hundred <a href="Film">cinema</a> and <a href="television%20film">television film</a>s, including "<a href="Investigation%20Held%20by%20ZnaToKi">Investigation Held by ZnaToKi</a>" (1985), "<a href="We%20Are%20from%20Jazz">We Are from Jazz</a>" (1983), "<a href="Neznayka%20with%20Our%20Court">Neznayka with Our Court</a>" (1983) and the "<a href="In%20port">In port</a>" animated film.
His awards included an Honoured Cultural Worker of Russia Federation, Laureate Awards of the All-<a href="Soviet%20Union">Union</a> and International composer contests.
He was the President of the Russian Cinematic Composers Guild, an acting member of the Russian Cinematic Academy <a href="Nika%20Award">Nika Award</a>, a member of the Composers Union (1970), and a member of the Cinematographers Union (1981).
Early life and career.
Minkov was born in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, <a href="USSR">USSR</a>. He attended the Merzlyakovki Conservatory School where he studied composition under <a href="Nikolay%20Sidelnikov">Nikolay Sidelnikov</a>. He then studied under <a href="Aram%20Khachaturian">Aram Khachaturian</a> at the <a href="Moscow%20Conservatory">Moscow Conservatory</a> in 1964.
He was awarded the Golden <a href="Pushkin">Pushkin</a> Medal (1999) for "his contribution to the development, preservation and multiplication of the national cultural traditions, help and support of the creative <a href="intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a>, and development and forming of newer styles and directions in culture".
A song by Minkov based on the lyrics "Invisible struggle" (<a href="Transliteration">translit.</a> Nezrimiy Boi - "If somebody, somewhere among us, sometimes...") by <a href="Anatoly%20Gorokhov">Anatoly Gorokhov</a> is featured in almost all the series. It became an unofficial <a href="hymn">hymn</a> of the <a href="Soviet%20Militia">Soviet Militia</a>. In 2001, he was awarded the <a href="MVD">MVD Russian Interior Ministry</a> award for the music theme to the Sledstvie vedut znatoki.
In 2003, Minkov became a <a href="People%27s%20Artist%20of%20Russia">People's Artist of Russia</a>.
